column1: Facial nerve palsy due to birth trauma is the loss of controllable (voluntary) muscle movement in an infant's face due to pressure on a certain nerve in the face just before or at the time of birth.

Some factors that can cause birth trauma (injury) include: - Large baby size (may be seen if the mother has diabetes) - Long pregnancy or labor - Use of epidural anesthesia - Use of a medication to cause labor and stronger contractions Most of the time, these factors do not lead to facial nerve palsy or birth trauma.

The newborn infant may have the following symptoms: - Eyelid may not close on affected side - Lower face (below eyes) appears uneven during crying - Mouth does not move down the same way on both sides while crying - No movement (paralysis) on the affected side of the face (from the forehead to the chin in severe cases)
Infants with permanent paralysis need special therapy.
A parent, grandparent, or other person may notice the problem later.
There is no guaranteed way to prevent pressure injuries in the unborn child.
